utterances: TV naturalist David Attenborough is among those lending his voice to the cause, citing past recommendations of the government's own scientists.
(SOUNDBITE OF TELEVISION PROGRAM)
Culling is not a viable policy option.
British rock star turned animal welfare campaigner, Brian May, argues that vaccination not eradication is the answer.
Farmers have been killing badgers for many, many years now.
And effectively, we're in a cull situation already and TB is rampant.
But conservative British lawmaker Simon Hart says thousands of badgers must die to save thousands of cows and the family farms that depend on them.
Nobody wants to do this.
There's no sense of glee here.
We've explored every option, taken veterinary advice, and reluctantly come to the view that this, with other things, is the only way we can nail this disease once and for all.
Permits have been granted in the counties of Somerset and Gloucestershire.
But the government will not reveal more precisely where the killings will begin or when: just sometime this fall and after dark, of course, because badgers are nocturnal.
That's already affected country life in those areas.
Gordon McGlone runs the Gloucestershire Wildlife Trust.
We have staff who are very devoted and work very hard on our nature reserves.
And they do lots of things that perhaps one wouldn't expect; bat walks, walks in dusk and dawn.
We've stopped that because we don't want to put them at risk,
Their legal bid to stop the cull defeated, some animal welfare groups are now considering protests and consumer boycotts.
Britain's RSPCA is urging shoppers to refuse to buy, in its words, milk from farms soaked in badgers' blood.
For NPR News, I'm Vicki Barker in London.
Boeing's Dreamliner aircraft has made its introductory flight on the world stage.
The company's newest plane is critical to Boeing's future, but it's been plagued by nearly three years of delays.
The twin-engine jetliner flew into the Farnborough International Airshow in Southern England yesterday.
That's the biggest and most important industry trade show.
Vicki Barker reports.
(Soundbite of airplane engine)
The world's first mostly carbon fiber jetliner dropped from the clouds like a feather, the model number standing out in white italics on a royal blue tail.
(Soundbite of airplane engine)
The 787 Dreamliner, flying into massive interest from the global media, as well as aviation enthusiasts like Mary B.
Lyons.
Well, I had to see the Dreamliner.
I've just been longing to see it land.
I've got some great photographs.
It's a very aircraft, and it's pointing the way to the future.
In a world of growing economic and environmental uncertainty, that future is leaner, greener and ever more globalized.
The nose comes from Wichita.
The neck section comes from Japan, and the back section is Italy.
It's a 93 lifetime with the American Conservative Union.
Yes, the Time reporter who has been at the center of this controversy, Matt Cooper, wrote an essay about how he finally testified to the grand jury last week.
And as you remember, this was a major confrontation between him and the special prosecutor who wanted him to testify and was going to send him to jail if he wouldn't.
And another reporter from The New York Times, Judith Miller, actually has gone into federal detention because she won't testify about this.

So now we wanted to know, of course, what Matt Cooper was testifying, finally going before the grand jury, and he told us in Time over the weekend, essentially telling us that Karl Rove was the first person who indicated to him the identity of the CIA official who sent Joe Wilson off to Niger to check out the uranium weapons of mass destruction rumor back in 2002.
And all of this has real meaning because it was a big part of the justification that the administration put together for the invasion of Iraq.
And didn't the president say he would fire anyone involved in that disclosure?
Yes, he did, back when the case first got rolling, and he reiterated it last year in 2004.
But now today, he said he is still committed to firing anyone who has committed a crime.
And so where does this all end?

Well, it's not going to end too soon, I don't believe, because the special prosecutor, Patrick Fitzgerald, has until October to bring back an indictment if there's going to be one, either for a crime or perhaps for obstruction of justice or for perjury.
He has until October with this grand jury, and we don't know where it's going to end.
In the meantime, another brewing story: We may get a new Supreme Court nominee, and then the confirmation wars.

Yes, if the nominee is highly controversial, which is an excellent possibility because it doesn't take too much to be controversial in today's Senate, a very deeply divided body with the partisans of each side pushing things pretty hard.
But it is also possible that the president will come up with someone that can be pretty easily confirmed by consensus in the Senate.
That certainly was what happened 11 years ago when the last two Supreme Court justices got through, Stephen Breyer and Ruth Bader Ginsburg.
Well, I guess the big question would be then are there any nominees who would not trigger a big struggle?
It's interesting to speculate about Al Gonzales, the attorney general currently.
He's been more controversial among some elements of the president's conservative base than he has been with the Senate in general.
I think he probably could be confirmed fairly easily, with most of the objections to him being raised outside the Senate.
And meanwhile, Congress is working this week.
What are some of the big issues they're taking up there?
They're taking up the renewal of the Patriot Act in the House and, of course, the president wants 16 expiring provisions of the Patriot Act from 2001 to be made permanent.
I don't think all of them will be.

I think there's been enough controversy about some of them--library records, other things that the government can currently find out about you--that those provisions will be either altered or allowed to expire.
Over on the Senate side, they're going to be talking about stem cells.
The House has already voted to make it more possible for the federal government to fund embryonic stem cell research, and I think they're going to do something of that kind in the Senate, as well.
NPR senior Washington editor Ron Elving.
He writes the Web column Watching Washington for npr.org.
(Soundbite of music)
Stay with us on DAY TO DAY from NPR News.
Now we're going to talk about one reason sanctions against North Korea have not worked so far.
The country uses shell companies to avoid the rules that the international community tries to impose.
Anthony Ruggiero is a former State Department and Treasury official who now tracks this issue for the right-leaning think tank the Foundation for the Defense of Democracies.
Welcome to the program.
Thanks for having me.
Give me an example of how one of these shell companies works.

So North Korea usually will have - either it will happen with their own representatives or they'll have - and the best example we have is of a Chinese company and individuals that will set up front companies for North Korea's operation.
And in that example, North Korea provided a commodity - in this case coal - for sale and then it was sold likely within China.
And that money was held inside China after a profit taken by the Chinese companies.
And then what North Korea essentially had was a pool of money that it could draw from to purchase materiel or luxury goods or whatever it needed.
But one thing it did not purchase, of course, was food or medicine or other types of material for their own people.
Shell companies are not in and of themselves illegal, right?
Right.
Front companies - it depends.
Obviously there are some other restrictions involved.
But in most cases the setting up of that company would not be illegal.
It's the activity that they're undertaking that could be against sanctions or against national laws or international laws.
How big a part of North Korea's economy is this?
Do we have any way of knowing?
Well, it's hard to know because North Korea does not report its own trade statistics.

So - and there's this whole - there's an illicit part of their economy as well where they're engaged in illicit activities, whether that's cyber activities or counterfeiting our currency at one point or counterfeit drugs or actually drug smuggling.
So they have a lot of different counterfeit activities that are hard for us to track.
Are these shell companies for the most part run by people who just want to make a buck, who might be associated with organized crime?
Or are they run by high-up government officials who could stop this on a wide scale if they wanted to?
Stanley, thanks very much for the call.
Appreciate it.
Thank you.
Now, this might seem a bit hypocritical, but it's just a bolder version of the doublespeak that you hear from many refugees.
Habiba Abdurhaman, a camp chairwoman, rattles off all the reasons that Somalia is not safe or suitable for her until she explains that the newer arrivals, the refugees that came post-2006.
